Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Additive manufacturing of ceramic composites for next generation gas turbines
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project lies in next generation gas turbines where the heart of the engine, the combustor and the blade, are constructed from ceramic matrix composites (CMCs). These developments will spell a new phase of air transportation beyond the current engines that rely upon nickel-base superalloys, which have reached their maximum capability. The ceramic engines are eventually expected to be 25% more efficient. The CMCs are constructed from fibers of silicon-carbide that are spun into net shape and then infiltrated with an equally robust high temperature matrix, also made from silicon carbide-based ceramics. The fiber composites overcome the inherent brittleness of monolithic ceramics while retaining their mechanical and corrosion resistance in aggressive environments. These composites will have applications beyond gas turbines. They can become the critical breakthrough for the solar collector on Concentrated Solar Power systems, and have the potential to be used as cladding for nuclear fuels for greater safety and accident tolerance. The key innovation in this Phase I project is the development of an additive manufacturing process for creating a dense and defect free matrix from polymer precursors that convert into silicon carbide-based ceramics.


This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project employs additive manufacturing to fabricate dense and defect free matrices for ceramic matrix composites (CMCs). These composites are constructed from fibers of silicon carbide (SiC). The innovation in this project lies in constructing the matrix from polymer precursors where nanoscale layers are deposited in quick succession to create the matrix. These silicon-based polymer precursors convert into ceramics when heated to ~800 oC. Nominal processing, also known as polymer-infiltration-and-pyrolysis, produces cracks in the matrix despite 24 hour curing cycles. These cracks degrade the strength of the composite. In this project nanoscale coatings are deposited in the form of thin layers of liquid and then pyrolyzed into the ceramic in just one or two seconds. The coatings are defect free and dense. The short curing time allows rapid deposition of layers. The CMC can be prepared from SiC fiber preforms in about four hours. The feasibility of the process has been demonstrated with carbon fibers under a grant from Ceramics Program at NSF. In this SBIR project, American Manufacturing LLC seeks to demonstrate the fabrication of CMCs made from silicon-carbide fibers, and demonstrate their viability for high temperature applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This STTR Phase I award to American Manufacturing Incorporated, Inc. (AMI) and the University of Colorado Boulder, was led by Mark N. Spowart as the PI at AMI, and Prof. Rishi Raj at the University of Colorado Boulder as the Co-PI. The primary goal of the project was to demonstrate the feasibility of employing an additive manufacturing method to create dense and defect free, highly refractory, polymer-derived ceramics (PDCs) matrices for ceramic-matrix-composites (CMCs) for next generation ultrahigh temperature gas turbine engines. The deployment of ceramics is expected to raise the operating temperature of engines up to 1500 oC and increase the operating efficiency by 30%. This target reaches beyond the performance of the current CMC technology, recently introduced by the General Electric Company into their LEAP engines. The GE method employs silicon melt infiltration to achieve a dense matrix; however, the residual silicon left behind limits the operating temperature of these CMCs. In this project the goal was to create the CMCs with a dense polymer-derived-ceramic (PDC) which is known to remain stable and resist creep and oxidation at temperatures up to 1500 oC.

 

The key barrier in the fabrication of PDC-CMCs is that the 50% shrinkage associated with polymer to ceramic conversion creates microcracks or flaws, despite very slow, day-long curing cycles. These flaws degrade the mechanical and oxidation properties of the composite. The innovation in this Phase I effort was to explore the application of Additive Manufacturing to create a dense and crack free matrix of PDCs for ceramic fiber preforms. The concept was to deposit nanolayer thin films of the polymer on the fiber surfaces with the expectation that they would convert into the ceramic in mere seconds; and being very thin, would remain free from defects (Fig. 1). In this way layers deposited additively (Fig. 2) would be used to create a dense matrix around the fiber preform at a rate that is several times faster than conventional polymer-impregnation-and-pyrolyis method (PIP). This has been the principle outcome of the project.

 

A summary of the additional Outcomes is as follows:

 

(i) The tensile mechanical properties of composites made by the additive manufacturing method have been shown to surpass those reported in literature for such composites made by the conventional PIP (polymer infiltration and pyrolysis) process.

 

(ii) Remarkable enhancements in oxidation resistance have been obtained by mutating the chemistry of the polymer precursor to create an oxide-nonoxide matrix material. The uniqueness of the additive manufacturing method has enabled this outcome.

 

(iii) Creep properties of the composites are shown to be enhanced by the oxide-nonoxide matrix described just above.

 

(iv) The additive manufacturing system has been automated for nanolayer-by-nanolayer deposition of the ceramic, which can run reliably without supervision.

 

(v) Two papers have been published, and a third under review, in the Journal of the American Ceramic Society on the research conducted during the STTR Phase I project: (1) “Additive Manufacturing of Ceramics enabled by Flash Pyrolysis of Polymer Precursors with Nanoscale Layers”, J Am Ceram Soc, 2016, and (2) “Additive Manufacturing of SiCN Ceramic Matrix for SiC Fiber Composites by Flash Pyrolysis of Nanoscale Polymer Films”, J Am Ceram Soc, 2016. A third paper entitled, “Oxidation resistance of SiC Fibers coated with polymer derived HfOSiCN by the additive-manufacturing method” is under review.

 

It is noteworthy that other applications of the Additive Method, in addition to CMCs have been explored. They are (i) creating several micrometer thick coatings on ceramic substrates for low friction applications in extreme environments, (ii) electrically conductive, mechanical robust and chemically inert membranes for waste water filtration that can remove organics by applying an electrical potential; they are made by partial infiltration of carbon fiber preforms to leave behind controlled porosity, and (iii) exploring the possibility of creating three-dimensional structures by our additive manufacturing technology.
